NAME

SYNOPSIS

DESCRIPTION

can be used to create new processes without fully copying the address space of the old process, which is horrendously inefficient in a paged environment. It is useful when the purpose of would have been to create a new system context for an differs from in that the child borrows the parent’s memory and thread of control until a call to or an exit (either by a call to or abnormally.) The parent process is suspended while the child is using its resources. returns 0 in the child’s context and (later) the pid of the child in the parent’s context. can normally be used just like It does not work, however, to return while running in the childs context from the procedure that called since the eventual return from would then return to a no longer existent stack frame. Be careful, also, to call rather than if you can’t since will flush and close standard I/O channels, and thereby mess up the parent processes standard I/O data structures. (Even with it is wrong to call since buffered data would then be flushed twice.)

SEE ALSO

DIAGNOSTICS

Same as for

BUGS

This system call will be eliminated when proper system sharing mechanisms are implemented. Users should not depend on the memory sharing semantics of as it will, in that case, be made synonymous to To avoid a possible deadlock situation, processes that are children in the middle of a are never sent or signals; rather, output or calls are allowed and input attempts result in an end-of-file indication.
